comments_student:
I would like to undertake education-focused dissertation under the keyword Educational Research, with the working title:
The Long-Term Educational Impact of COVID-19 on Key Stage Transitions in Science.
This project aligns closely with my career aspiration to become a secondary school science teacher and builds directly on my existing experience in both primary and secondary school settings. I have already established strong working relationships with local teachers, which will enable me to access meaningful data through interviews, surveys, and collaborative research.
I have create a one-note file and begun early planning and background reading around this topic, including literature on curriculum alignment, learning loss post-COVID, and science education transition strategies. 
My research will explore questions such as:
* To what extent has the COVID-19 pandemic affected students’ science readiness at secondary schooll level?
* Has the curriculum gap between primary and secondary widened since COVID?
* How effective are current transition and outreach strategies in science?
* What practical responses have teachers implemented to address observed knowledge or engagement dips?
This project will allow me to apply my academic background in Biomed to a relevant educational issue, while developing valuable skills in data collection, educational research methods, and real-world curriculum analysis. Given my access to schools and the feasibility of the research, I am confident this project will produce a thought through academic piece of writing.

I am highly motivated to undertake a laboratory-based research project, with a strong preference for topics related to emerging infections and pandemic threats, clinical drug development, and protein structure and function. I have hands-on experience working with various microorganisms and cell systems. Notably, I have cultured Dunaliella tertiolecta for β-carotene production under stress conditions (light filters, temperature, and pH), and worked with E. coli to study antimicrobial resistance (AMR) using antibiotics such as ampicillin and tetracycline.

Additionally, I completed a research internship project on enzyme kinetics involving Human MDH1 and Plasmodium falciparum MDH. This involved monitoring enzyme activity under different buffers, temperatures, and pH conditions. I also explored the structural and functional background of both enzymes to better understand their roles in metabolic pathways and pathogen-specific characteristics.

Through these experiences, I have developed proficiency in core laboratory techniques such as gel electrophoresis, microscopy, micro-pipetting, 96-well plate assays, and bacterial streaking methods. My academic background and practical training have strengthened my analytical skills and scientific curiosity. I am confident that I can contribute meaningfully to a project aligned with my interests, particularly in laboratory or computational settings focusing on infectious diseases and molecular biology.

I have previously carried out conservation work in Africa which has driven my interest in how trade policy affects elephant populations, local communities and enforcement efforts.

Like with regulated drug markets, the argument for legalising ivory trade hinges on controlling and taxing the trade to reduce demand, decrease illegal activity and improve oversight. I’d like to critically examine whether such regulation could offer a better alternative to total trade bans.

I would prefer a literature-based project rather than a laboratory or modelling project. Relevant topic areas include Animals in Society, Conservation Biology and Environmental Change and Animal Welfare Research.
